												After logging many hours on this game in the last two years, I finally decided to write a review. My taste in PC games mostly includes the strategy (especially turn based and pausable RTS) genre. I'm a fan of the X-Com Games, The Total War Series, Close Combat, etc. I played all of the Jagged Alliance Games and enjoyed them all. In my opinion, JABIA is a good game if you like this type of game; a game that requires a lot of management (inventory, strategy, assembling teams, et.). I found the planning and execution of my plans in this game a lot of fun. There are a few rough edges. They could have included a way to look at items ordered after you ordered them, as in the old JA Games. As it is now, you place the order and you have to remember what you ordered until it arrives and the only place it can arrive is at the Drassen Airport, requiring a lot of 'mule' trips by your mercs who will spend much of their time running back and forth for supplies and using newly hired mercs as mules when they come in. The end result of this is that I found myself spending much of my time organizing logistics for reenforcement and resupply. If, like me, you enjoy this in a game, then you won't mind it and may even have fun with it. If this kind of micro-management isn't to your taste, skip this game.The other part of the game is the tactical combat. This is done using a real time pausable system that requires many pauses and movement order updates during combat to be succesful (survive). With a small group of mercs (one or two teams of 6 each) it can be very exciting and great fun, but as the game goes on, and especially when you are getting ready for the final assaults on the enemy strongholds, you will probably have several dozen mercs going against hundreds of bad guys in just a few sectors. At this point the tactical combat becomes overwhelming as it is virtually impossible to be everywhere at once and are therefore forced to send a small group of mercs at a time against many enemies to whittle them down slowly, and it becomes a drawn out meat grinder of attrition. Not much sneaking around, tactical planning here. Just a whole bunch of shooting against very long odds. I think JA2 did much better by forcing the player, VIA limited finances and merc contracts, to run fewer teams and keep the game managable, while not requiring quite so many mercs to succesfully complete the game.  When you hire mercs in BIA, you pay the fee up front and they are yours for the whole campaign regardless of the length of time they work for you, and the money you find and earn in this game will easily run into the hundreds of thousands, so there is a balance issue here. Also, militia are pretty innafective, and when they die the weapons you equip them with dissapear. I found it much more effective, once you've been in the game for awhile to just leave teams of mercs within striking distance of primary towns and mines that you have captured and send them in when enemies try to attack. Mercs can move amazingly fast along roads and, as mentioned before, you'll have the money and therefore can afford the extra mercs to do the job.   Some things I really like about this game:-Friendly fire is a threat. This adds some realism that I welcome, especially with grenades and explosives. You don't have the automatic grenade placement of the new Xcom. "Watch out for that tree branch...Hit the dirt!"-The strategic logistical and organizational planning and the tactical planning for each sector. A lot of fun here if you like that sort of thing.-The great fun of fast moving firefights once you get used to the interface, especially when the skirmishes are small.There are some annoying bugs and design flaws, a few of which are:-In close combat you can't shoot at an enemy when he gets close to you. You'll hear comments like "Can't make the shot" and your merc will just stand there as the enemy soldier cuts you to pieces, even if you have a pistol or SMG.-Unlike the other good games in this series, you can't repair any equipment but weapons. Body armor just takes damage until it's useless, and it is very expensive.-Sometimes when told to fire repeatedly at one target, your mercs will cycle through the count-down time for aiming, then cycle through again without firing. They seem to be able to do this indefinately so you have to watch them carefully.-When in a firefight, mercs are often forced into a kneeling position (frequently exposing themselves to enemy fire) when doing certain tasks, like first aid, clearing a weapon or disarming a mine. This also happens when you try to arm a LAW (Light Anti-tank Weapon). This unfortunate glitch will get you hit fast!-Game stops working occasionally for no apperent reason ('JABIA has stopped working'). This doesn't happen often, but just when you are about to win an intense twenty minute firefight, it's a bit annoying.NOTE: There is a very good mod that helps this game quite a bit called the "Realistic Rebalancing Mod for Jagged Alliance - back in Action" by KILLATOMATE. I highly recommend using this mod to help some balancing issues and decrease the frequency of some glitches within the game.As it is, I find this to be a very good game that has a lot of replayability. It's interesting to start off with various combinations of mercs to build different teams, then progress theough the game by taking areas of the map over in different order, etc. If they had taken a little more time and care in the development of this game, it could have been great.

												This is a very tenuous thumbs up.  The pause/realtime system was indeed a break & a daring experiement for the franchise, but I think it works.  I'm not one of those "turn based purists" who think anything else is blasphemy.  I'm fine with it, actually.The characters are familiar, and most of returning player expectations are met in that it delivers what it says on the book - a reboot of JA2 into a new game engine.  The same systems are all in play, and that's a good thing.  It's got your sector-by-sector conquer and consolidate, your cheesy dialogs and plenty of gun-fetish to go around.But it also falls flat in some areas.  Any real firearms enthusiast can find a hundred different flaws, errors and downright screw-ups in that equipment list.  The AI, both friendly and enemy, is questionable at best.  A lot of the light humor from JA2 has either turned dark or disappeared.  With the helicopter removed, supply logisitics are simply nightmarish, now.  Most offensive of all, Elliot is gone.However, all that being said... when I look at this game and compare it to all the increasingly horrible crap out there that tries to leech JAs name whilst simulataneously grinding that name into the mud... I find myself compelled to defend the easily superior quality of this product on general principle.The combat is still solid (usually), the tactics still interesting, the new problems that each town presents still challenging, and overall... yes, it's still fun.  Far from perfect, but fun.In short, it is not the best JA game out there, but at least I can say is really is a proper JA game and not some crappy knock-off and/or wannabe junk.  It may just be JA2's ugly brother, but it's still family.  That's more than I can say for the rest of the garbage out there.

Guns also can't be fired in melee range, apparently, and melee hits register still after the target is ten meters away.Lots of potential, but poor execution and lack of steady progression killed the fun for me way too quick. 												This review is for the Windows version. The MAC/Linux version is unplayable at this point.I am a fan of JA2 and i was quite disappointed when JABIA was released. It was unfinished and overpriced on release. But things have changed. Most of the game's problems can be fixed by using mods and the price of the game has decreased considerably. I played the modded Windows version for 220 hours and really enjoyed it. I can only recommend this game.The story/scheme of the game is very similar to JA2: You are hired to liberate a small 3rd world country and can only afford to send in a few wannabe mercenaries. You start to liberate/loot remote locations in order to get your hands on more money and better weapons while you recruit NPCs and improve their skills.In contrast to JA2 this game is in 3D and in real time. Which is awesome in my opinion. You dont have to watch 40 AI moves until it is your turn. You can pause and intervene at any time. The game offers a lot of freedom. You can run away from tough battles and come back later with better equipment. You can even leave the first battle of the game and explore instead.There are a few flaws, however:-Mercs have less character compared to JA2 and there is no option to create your own mercenary.-AI is just as stupid as in JA2 and attack squads are very predictable-Animations in this game feel like placeholders (all weapons have same reload animation and sound)-Annoying melee combat. Guns cannot be fired at melee range and melee hits damage all of your gear.-Explosives (C4) can only be placed on brittle walls. you cannot set traps for enemies.-You will spend a lot of time managing your inventory-Militia is not very useful and recruiting is tedious.-You cannot train/repair/heal on the strategical map (which was a nice feature in JA2)-Enemies cheat / have superhuman skill (fixed by mod)-Weapons are imbalanced and have wierd stats (fixed by mod)-Broken Stealth: enemies hear you walk/climb from up to 150m (fixed by mod)-Broken Camouflage: camouflage not working properly, especially at night (fixed by mod)People also complain about horrible aimtime in CQC, but this can be solved by using the Run stance (F3) at close range. 												It is such a shame that Jagged Alliance went on to be one of the most abused franchises in the gaming industry. By "abused" I mean that pretty much every release with the name JA slapped on it was a huge disappointment when compared to JA2 (on which I spent so many hours, I could've built a spaceship using only a spoon in that time).Anyway, let's talk about BIA.BIA is quite an awkward game. On one hand it's a fresh approach to the genre and the title, on the other hand it sometimes makes you want to pistol-whip the living daylights out of the developers.PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE MODDED VERSION (using either Combat Evolved or the Realistic Rebalancing Mod). The vanilla game will disappoint you. Plain and simple. The combat system. The combat system is in real-time, yet it can be paused at any moment, and orders can be queued to your soldiers. It's awkwardly good - it needs a lot of getting used to, but once you get a hang of it, you can use it to your advantage and it's fun. Still, sometimes combat gets confusing, mainly when you're attacking using multiple teams. The graphics. They're alright. They do the trick. Camera angles may get weird sometimes, but usually they're ok. Sounds. Pretty much the same as the graphics. The voiceover isn't great, but it's not a deal-breaker. Gameplay. It can get challenging, you'll get lots of gameplay hours out of it. The UI is ok, I've seen worse. Stability is ok, although the game has some tendencies to crash on you. What disappointed me a little was the lack of the lovely JA2 humour, with the Deidranna cutscenes missing altogether and other details not incorporated at all (like the florist website and many other things). BIA tries to take a more serious approach and fails, since humour was a big part of what made JA2 so much fun.The AI is a mixed bag, one fight they'll just run towards you and get mowed down, a few moments later they'll use cover and cause some serious trouble.I played BIA using both of the aforementioned mods (in two separate gameplays, of course) and it was fun. They fixed a lot of issues, brought in tons of new guns and modifications, Combat Evolved also gave you access to a lot of old friends from JA2.So, do I recommend this game?Yes, as long as you mod it. You miss out on a lot playing the vanilla game.The modded version gives you a touch of good ol' Sir Tech JA2, so if you're a long-time fan, don't even bother playing BIA straight out of the box.Of all the other JA clones or "remakes" out there, this is probably the best one.

												I am 50+ hours into this game, and I mean to complete it.After going through all the mixed reviews for this game, I decided to wait for a sale and try it out. I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. IF you're expecting some sort of revolutionary (or evolutionary) successor in the JA franchise, you're going to be disappointed. Back In Action is not that -- it's a re-envisioned, updated version of Jagged Alliance 2, with the ultimate aim of liberating Arulco from Deidrianna. Graphics are now 3D, and the game engine is "real-time" but combat can be paused for you to issue orders/commands. The nice thing about this system is that you can simultaneously coordinate attacks from different entry points, create overlapping fields of fire, ambush enemies stealthily with a knife, etc.Some things have been simplified too: you only pay for your merc once. Militia recruitment is simplified (all you need is to arm them). And you cannot create your own character (this was fun in the original JA2, but I'm not convinced absolutely essential).The game focuses mainly on combat. In JA2 it was turn based, here, it's real-time with pausing enabled. Sight lines and physics seem ok. Can things go wrong? Of course. Just as they do in real life. So pay no mind to those who expect their tactics and plans to be executed perfectly. But that's part of the realism, and to me, the appeal of this JA title. Some things I didn't like: no helo transport (am going everywhere on foot, which is a pain) thus far, no ETA for my online orders at Drassen, no crafting of special items, inability to repair anything except weapons (though this can be thought of as realism I guess -- how can your merc repair everything from guns to knives to armor? Seriously?).Still I paid $11 for this title when on sale, got 2 extra DLC mission packs, and some mediocre firearms in some other packs. Based on that, I'm going to recommend this game. Get it when it's on sale. It's really quite fun!6.5/10.0

												This could have been a great game. It had the potential to be a worthy successor to the excellent JA1 and JA2 games of our youth. Nice graphics, a decent combat system. Unfortunately, it seems they never really got round to finishing the game. It's like they cut a load of corners, spent too much time designing junk items (like a wide variety of t-shirts and food items), didn't properly test it, rushed it to market and then started on the DLC cashgrab as soon as they could.A few gripes and missing features :There's several really annoying bugs (for example, items in sector inventory will disappear randomly and only reappear if you save and reload). Gameplay is unbalanced - expect to face off against skilled, well-armed enemies with your two or three pistol-wielding mercs pretty early on. If you move into an occupied sector, expect to be dumped right next to the enemy forces - you need to move next to the danger area and manually enter the zone if you want to try any kind of stealthy approach.There are cars and lorries all over the landscape but none of them are usable. Forget about quick transport between locations.Explosives can only be used at specific weak points in walls so forget about making your own entrance to a building. You'll often find locks that can't be picked or forced. You can't shoot locks or blow up doors. Mercs and militia will happily jump on landmines, even when they've been detected. There's no autopause when a mine is detected, either, so if you're sending a merc through a potentially mined area, do so carefully.The militia system has been horribly simplified. Rather than go through the tedium of vetting recruits and teaching them to use guns, why not just hand that random person on the street, potentially violent prisoner in a locked cell or hospital patient found in a locked ward an assault rifle? What could possibly go wrong?Only one weapon attachment is allowed at a time and is removed if you change weapons. Want a silencer, laser sight and fancy optics on that gun? Forget it. Want to switch to another gun when your inventory is full? Drop something first.Shooting an enemy will interrupt and stun them (fine, that's a good idea) yet hitting them with a baseball bat or machete doesn't, allowing the enemy a chance to beat the snot out of your merc.IMP no longer exists. Forget about making your own merc.Enjoyed those witty interactions between mercs or those cutscenes of Deidranna abusing her staff in JA2? Interesting, well-written dialogue with NPCs? You won't find them here. By the time you're storming the palace you'll just want the game to be over and done with.Conclusion : Meh. Don't bother. Unless it's really, really cheap in a sale.

Jagged Alliance 2, simply put, is the king of the small, but proud sub-genre of strategies, namely, a squad-based tactical wargames. JA Back in Action is the 3d re-vision of classical JA2, with new engine based on real-time action with commanding pause mode. To my regret, I wasn’t impressed with that cover-version, so I’m not gonna persuade you to buy it. Game’s decent, even engaging sometimes, but really not that much as original JA2. Even with the all downsides that original Jagged Alliance 2 have, it is still a much better game than its remake Back in Action.Short audition of features:1) 3d view works fine enough, but I can’t say same thing about control above the camera view. Due to real-time gaming pattern, I often was in the not-so-fun position where I can see neither enemies, nor my own soldiers in the middle of the shootout. Somebody’s shooting, but who? On whom? It was not obvious way too often. The biggest throw-down of the given 3D engine is not a bad camera, though. It is very limited destructibility. You have plenty of C4 there, but you only allowed blowing certain points at every sector. You can’t even open closed door with the shotgun!2) All controls are giving the feeling that developers were in need to invent a wheel anew. Or at least, a bicycle. Even moving a map from side to side with the sliding of mouse was added after some patches. And when you‘ll make yourself familiar with the basic controls, you’ll still be wandering with some “decisions” about user interface. Like management of your mercs in teams, or management of inventory of taken sectors.3) Smart pause mode itself is good, comparing only with the best examples in the genre. But crude AI behavior and sometimes ridiculous camera makes that modus not so desirable, so to say. It is still a good option, but not the essential, like in games on Apeiron engine (7.62, Marauder) or even in the Dragon Age titles.4) AI of the enemies… they shoot precisely, even with the weakest of weapons, but instead of taking the advantage of those superb skills, they always tend to rush forward, by the shortest path available. And they don’t give much attention to the dead bodies of their comrades, if they don’t heard a shot or seen the shooter. In short, they are quite dumb. There are several maps in the game, where some additional rules were added to enemies behavior, and it is there you’ll probably meet some troubles, and get an urge to plan something ahead. 3-4 serious fights in the whole game, I’d say it’s not enough, but that’s me. Someone likes easy games, and the majority of games now are making for those casual players. So take a hint: buy some PSG-1 rifles and collimators, to shoot far and precise enough, and quite fast at the same time. With those rifles you’ll be having the upper hand almost in every situation that game has for you.By the way! The AI of guards you’re hiring for defending your sectors… it’s the same as with soldiers, but even worse! They don’t use any tactical advantages of the defending position; they just rush on the bullets! And, unlike the Jagged Alliance 2, you can’t just hire new guards via global map. You need to get some guns, go to the sector where the fight with Deidranna forces was, arm manually each new volunteer… And if he dies, he won’t leave his gun on the body, you need to find or buy a new one. So you need to participate in every fight by yourself, and it will be faster that way.I can keep up with that list, but that’s major things: the game went in 3D, but became much plainer in the process, if we compare it with the vanilla Jagged Alliance 2. Back In Action took almost everything that wasn’t so necessary and fun, like over-pompious music themes, and constant transitions of items between sectors. A 3D perspective is not bad to have, and smart pause mode can be tolerable. But illogical and un-informative camera views, clumsy controls and blunt behavior of any opponents are not giving the taste of satisfaction even when you prevail above them.Take me right, I’m not thinking that the Jagged Alliance is a perfect game, even if I’m calling it the king of the tactical genre. Were it up to me, I’d cut or remade some features from it as well, and all that constant fuss with the inventory items, which need to fix, optimize, transfer from sector to sector, from drop zone to battle lines – in the first hand. I’d add some really fitting and atmospheric music to the background, just to fight the urge to fell asleep over the keyboard, while I’m planning another phase of ongoing war conflict. And to think more of it… Maybe the most challenging thing that was made under the brand of Jagged Alliance was not that 2nd game we’re so much talking about? Maybe it is the add-on to the first Jagged Alliance, the Deadly Games? There you have a line of separated missions for your squad of mercs. You have one map, where you fixing all your tasks, and after it, that’s all, you’re victorious! It feels much more refined, than questionable economic system of the JA2 game. The developers of Back In Action thought in that direction as well. They made two DLC with such maps, in every case you have some quest to get in somewhere and kill there somebody, via some sub-stages on the way. Sadly, but both of those DLC’s are just shown how amateur those developers are. There are different reasons for this conclusion, but hear this: in the mission Shades of Red you need to storm some embassy where hostages are being held. The developers make the several ways to get to that embassy, and the cleverest one was from the basement, which you can penetrate via sewerage tunnel. That way you don’t need to dodge the rockets, which the insurgents will be shooting in case of direct assault. But, but, but… In the end the devs decided it is not good for balance, so now you can’t get to embassy via tunnel. You see it from one end near the river, you can get there with a C4 blast through the wall. But you can’t go further to the tunnel. After you storm the embassy in the hardest, direct assault way, you get down to the basement, and then you see another end of that tunnel, and you realizing, how far Back In Action from the real complete state. Even now, after 3 years after release, with all after-market fixes, like adding the possibility to use mouse to move the map… it is still far from complete, not only in the DLC maps, but in the major game as well.Finally, so many words after, a conclusion: you CAN buy the Back In Action, if you have a thing for tactical games. It is not a bad game; it is playable and sometimes even brings some fun!I’ll mark it 6.5/10. It looks good, it sounds and feels almost like old-good Jagged Alliance. Simple-sized for newer, casual players (who can forgot to reload gun between getting into the fights, for example) – but still you controlling a team of mercs, and still you’re in the lead of private war going in the colorful little Latin country. You may find many mods, honing the improvements Back In Action made to Jagged Alliance franchise. There are not so many games in the genre, after all, and Back In Action is certainly not in the worst part of that list.

Remember that you are a part of a STRUGGLING rebel group trying to overthrow a goverment, so expect it to be difficult to kill hundreds of soldiers with a couple squads of 6 or less mercs(though you can have multiple squads in the same location, you'll just have to tab between them). You can expect to lose and replace squad members(unless you're a fan of copious saving and reloading), and you may have to retreat a few times, but with the right prep work a single mid-level merc can take out a squad of 15 without taking a hit. You MUST have a strategy in mind before moving in, and you must learn to be flexible. As the in-game time progresses, locations receive more and more reinforcements, so you must act quickly to secure a few early and get your daily income up to otherwise the entire game will be an uphill battle. Arming the locals is crucial, unless you leave some mercs behind to defend against the ai squads which is a good idea in a few locations. For those who say this game is too hard, I would be happy to write a strategy guide(not a walkthrough), but only if someone comments that they would like one, not going to spend the time if no-one is going to read it.

												(BEAT THE GAME YEARS AGO OFF STEAM, GOING AT IT AGAIN!)If you're a fan of JA 1 and 2, you NEED to at least try this game.Don't pay the nay-sayers any heed, this is a GREAT game, especially if you use the Realistic Rebalancing Mod. This is sort of a community patch, changing some broken weapons and buggy systems for the greater good.http://www.moddb.com/mods/realistic-rebalancing-modBasically, it's JA2's story. The government coup, payed for by a handful of diamonds late at night on the streets of prague. Dedrianna is still the main antagonist, though the cinematics featuring her and Elliot (idiot!) are missing.You do NOT have a personal avatar this time around, instead you hire starting mercenaries with a small starting fund. It's about enough to get three beginner mercs with basic armaments. You'll see a lot of familiar faces in the merc roster, but they have a lot less personality than previous titles. The UI is a rather drab green colour, and there is less exposition in this game. Each merc only needs to be payed a one-time, flat rate for their contract. No repeated costs. For balance reasons, mercs are now very expensive.To make up for the lack of flair, BIA features a more streamlined combat and logistics system. There is only one airstrip, just north of drassen. You capture it straight away, and can start ordering guns and mercs in the first day with little difficulty. Shipping weapons and items to the front-lines can be done by one merc, and is a simple task. Though you may find it taking quite a while to arm up, this should come as no surprise to vets of the series. Capturing an area will leave any items discovered during battle in the item section of that area on the world map. No need to run around grabbing stuff.Recruiting NPC militia is a little more annoying this time around. You have to actually run about in the map to each recruit, and hand them a gun. You can use the area inventory for this, or your character's personal inventory. It's annoying, but this makes it so you can have some pretty serious militia. If you leave just one merc in the area to help out with combat, a well-armed militia can make short work of anyone attempting to re-capture your towns. Upgrading the militia's skills is done from the world map, just click on the town or house or whatever, and you get a simple menu at the bottom left for progressively more expensive level-ups.There are some hiccups with the combat system. Controls seem a little janky, as far as contemporary tactics games go. You need to manually enable auto-attack (guard) mode for your mercs at the start of every battle. Otherwise, they'll sit around yelling at you while they get helplessly massacred. Panning around the scene will prevent you from using buttons to change stance and such, and the queue-based command system that BIA uses during the Pause screen in combat can be tough to get used to. If you take the time to learn to use it though, you'll find each fight works itself out a lot faster than JA2 combat ever did. This can make easier battles fly by in a devestating hail of gunfire, instead of a protracted hour-long clickfest.BIA doesn't let you zoom out as far as I would like, but you can zoom the camera down with the mousewheel, and view the combat from a sort of soldier's-eye view. This is good for longer-range engagements, and looks pretty cool.The Rebalancing Mod adds some extra weapons, there's a pretty decent number of available guns in the game with that installed. They're all reasonably well balanced, and combat is a brain-over-brawn affair. You need to have really good unit placement and firing lines to be successful, especially when your enemy finally starts getting high powered rifles and body armor. Saving when you're in combat is impossible, so you can't cheese the shot rolls. It's a good way of doing it, as the game will auto-save every time you get spotted by the enemy. You can easily retry an engagement, and since the combat is so fast-paced, this really doesn't seem to be that big of a pain.The entire map seems to be rendered in 3d, so if you encounter an enemy patrol in the middle of nowhere, you will fight in a forest or desert just like in JA2. That being said, the 3d world battle map is surprisingly small. You may find that starting combat in a field will also include the nearby town, and you'll end up on the side of a HUGE combat map. Approach direction, and party location is very important for starting battles. You can easily place your squad in a specific street or courtyard using the world map, and then wait for the enemy to step into your auto-battle range. It's a really nice feature that works very well for multi-squad engagements, and planned attack missions. Want to approach from the west side of the village because it's got no sandbag walls? Load the game back to the map and circle around!Really, seriously consider giving this game a go. Right now it's non-sale price is $15 USD. There is a LOT of fun to be had here for that price.

												It is considered bad business, when attempting to do a remake/sequel of a product, ignore what was it's most shining qualities. Jagged Alliance 2 was known for it's turn-based strategy, degree of micromanagement that rewarded those with a shred finanical planning with a bigger margin of error, and memorable characters with very unique voices and facial graphics. Jagged Alliance 2 was a shining example from the old era of games, when PCs could only go so far on graphics and had to focus on the actual depth of the game. This is a facet that some Indie Companies are returning to. So now we come to the "remake" of Jagged Alliance 2, Jagged Alliance 2: Back in Action.I acquired this game by an Ebay sale, for $10, and still feel that I got ripped off. I have tried to play this game, wanting to love it cause of it's heritage, in which I spent long hours with Jagged Alliance 2. However, this so-called 'Innovative' Plan-N-Go function is not only a slap in the face to what was a main fun point of JA2, but is clunky in it's own execution. Plan-N-Go is not innovative. It isn't really 'Turn-Based'. All it is, is just Pausable Real-Time, with a very obtuse method of programming in moves. It creates a situation however where you have to pause constantly, as no planned tactics really go according to plan. Why the developers ignored the fans, who didn't want this development, I simply will not understand.The characters are..bland. The facial graphics are horrid, the voice acting is just horrible, and how this new game can do WORSE in this area, from it's decade old original just outright boggles me.The music is good. Very good, so good I wish I could extract the music files and then just delete the game and be done with it.Graphics? Yes, it has pretty graphics. Then again, so do all other games out now from big bucks studios. Pretty graphics is no longer a selling point, as many gamers are actually turning away from games that brag about graphics as they realize these games have just graphics..and nothing else. JA: BiA is a good example of this.The DLC focus and the sudden expansion hint at the companies own realization that they released a stinker of a game with very limited shelf life. Their content release, with attached price-tags, show they aren't really proud of this game and are looking to just cash in as soon as possible before a better version is released.Should you buy this game? Only if the price drops below that of a 16 oz. Pepsi. But spend your money on the Pepsi instead, as you'll get more enjoyment out of it. Pirate this game. The developers don't deserve a single penny. Money should be given for good products, not handed over to people who push out a horrible product, and laugh when you expect some actual quality for your investment.I am hoping the developers of Jagged Alliance: Flashback look at this game, and see within it, a tale on what NOT to do.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												Jagged Alliance:  Back in Action is an exercise in compromises between improving an already good strategy game and keeping it true to the original. On one hand, the graphics are definitely better and the 3d aspect adds a lot to the overall look and feel of the game. On the other hand, the real-time battle system can be a real turnoff to purists looking for a straight upgrade to the original series.Other than the graphical and audio updates, most of the game is the same. You still have to save Arulco from the evil Deidranna and must do so by recruiting mercenaries, liberating towns, and stocking up on the latest military hardware. Combat tends to be a bit more frantic this time around, since it’s no longer turn-based, and you will have to find whatever method gets you the most success with the least number of loaded saves. On my playthrough I found that having a trio of snipers and three assault-style mercs set up in a layered line formation in guard mode (auto-attack) tended to work really well and I could just un-pause the game while they murdered everything with very few interruptions needed (your experience may vary). The game is unfortunately, not without its issues, hence the mixed rating on steam store. Determining line-of-sight is an absolute chore and the graphical interface does very little to help you determine the topology of the map you’re fighting on. This can lead to your characters being more exposed than you think they are and/or not able to fire on an enemy. This is aggravated a bit by the fact that your player must have a high perception score in order to automatically fire on far away targets in guard mode. While this isn’t a problem at the beginning of combat, when you suddenly have more enemies coming into the battle and have to start micro-managing forces it can become a bit of a pain.JA:BIA is another one of those games that makes you wish that Steam allowed for neutral ratings. I managed an entire playthrough and even enjoyed figuring out how to clear some of the maps, but I still wouldn’t rate this as a particularly “great” game, just an “okay” one that’s good for one playthrough and really moreso for people who aren’t religious Jagged Alliance fans (who would probably hate this game to death.)

												I want to like this game. I really want to. It is a shame that after Jagged Alliance 2 this franchise has been savaged at a pretty good clip.A continuation of the Jagged Alliance series that doesn't quite fit the bill. At times this game can be HIGHLY and EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING, as the bullet physics simply do not MAKE SENSE. I have had to replay scenario after scenario simply because my sniper who is equipped with a .50 cal barrett and a sniper scope is somehow unable to make a shot within 5 seconds that somehow bounces off an incoming enemy who is running towards my prone merc anticipating a shot. Jagged Alliance 2 was an amazing game. The characters each had their personalities and idiosyncrasies. This game comes across as feeling flat as there is zero dialogue between mercs.This game could have been so much more yet the devs failed on a variety of key points.1.) In this new series, your merc is UNABLE to repair armour. What does this mean? It means that you have to essentially shlep a merc back and forth, running orders for new armour. This translates into a huge waste of time and a waste of money. The game is seriously derailed because after a while you lose your armour and every single enemy AI you encounter has brand new armour. Lame.2.) The game is highly unbalanced and the devs are incompetent about this. It requires Ivan 6 seconds using a Barrett .50 cal with a scope to take a shot and all of his attributes are 90+ across the board. Yet it takes an enemy AI 2 seconds standing up to squeeze round after round and Ivan is dead before he gets a shot off. Idiotic.3.) It took me a record FIVE SHOTS from a PSG-1 50 feet away to drop an enemy AI. Each shot the enemy just shook it off. One shot alone with a 7.62 round 50 feet away to your head and your head would magically disappear into a fine mist. And yet the dev at BitComposer overlook this glaring fact.4.) Waiting patiently works against you. By the time I was ready and good to attack major cities, the number of enemy AI had bloated to over 80 a city. It took me around 3 hours of repeated saving and trying before I was able to take over the Docks which had 40 dead enemies. Ridiculous.5.) Enemy AI shooting mechanics are UNREALISTIC. I have had a merc prone some 50 feet away on an incline, which means he is facing the slope before having reached it. The other side the enemy AI has somehow managed to SHOOT ME THROUGH THE ♥♥♥♥ING HILL. Seriously...6.) Enemy AI will spot you miles down the road. Camouflage does not work. I have had snipers prone among trees and grass blended right in and the AI has been able to see me and also SHOOT ME THROUGH TREES AND ROCKS.7.) Camouflage counts for nothing.8.) The game forces you to heavily rely on micromanagement of cities with its system of hiring miltia. In Jagged Alliance 2 you could simply equip militia and watch a quick run through as they fount incoming troops. Whatever leftover troops were automatically leveled up. After a while, you could have a full compliment of militia and ANY town would be safe. In Back in Action, the computer will forever send 10 man teams to Cambria. Seeing that Cambria is an important city with its arms dealer, you are forced to park mercs to defend it. 9.) Regular militia are essentially useless. Edit: Over 70 hours of game play and I still recommend the game. Especially when on sale.I've completed about 70% of the main campaign + 2 DLC missions. I've got 10 mercs and playing on Hard the game still doesn't seem to be easy. Though I never bough any additional mercs (probably would have been too easy going with Scully and Gus and Magic), I'm doing ok with my first choice (Wolf) and the rest found along my journey. Iggy is pretty good as well. Dynamo, Conrad and Miguel almost maxed out. So... I'll keep on playing. :)I've played hundreds of hours with the original Jagged Alliance 2. I loved that game, and that was the main inspiration when I bought Jagged Alliance Back in Action. It is hard not to compare the two. I think we should rate this game on its own merit, not comparing it to it's "predecessor". I'll try to restrain myself from doing that. I'll try to make the "review" as if I never played Jagged Alliance 2.First of all, I definitely recommend this game. Here's why:- nice strategy elements- lots of guns- mercenaries from a wide range of characters- many different ways to play the game (sneak, melee, long range, spray'n'pray, explosives & traps :), etc)- for £7.5 sale price you get a complete game, 2 DLC missions and 1 extension pack with a new campaign. Just the extra content offers more than 24 hour game play. Definitely worth the money.- graphics is OK- sound is OKThere are a couple of downsides though:- original £25 might be a bit too expensive for the game.- sometimes it crashes (at least on my computer) therefore you have to save often. That pretty much solves the issue.- ALT + TAB can cause a crash as well (see previous point)- there is an exploit in the game that allows you to finish it in less than 24 hours game time (still you'll play days in real life though :)) When you move on the world map, it takes time. However moving in the tactical map (location map) time is frozen. So you go to the edge of the tactical map, switch to world map, go to the next location, and as soon as you enter, you stop the time and go to the new tactical map. All it takes in game time is 1-5 minutes. Otherwise it would take hours to travel from location to location.- sometime things don't make sense (e.g.: you can blow up a wall from one side but not from the other, or guns might get jammed while you melee someone with them. lol)- level cap is 10. It feels a bit low. I could do so much more...All in all the game feels OK, if you like tactical games, you'll like this one as well. If you are very critical towards it and you try to compare it to JA2, then you'll be a bit disappointed (unable to create your own character, level cap, less guns (still quite a lot!), less tactical, less things to customize, etc.)

												Fired this game up after a pause(~6month) and LOL-d hard at the very beginning, on the first hire: "Fidel is not himself lately. And it´s not a bad thing". Haven´t finished the prequels- tried them as a kid a bit- and maybe this game isn´t like the prequels, but it doesn´t mean it´s bad to the bones. The characters are funny and the whole game has the "parody thing" going on. The best thing about JABIA is the camera handling imo. With ALT key it´s possible to peak behind every corner and with aided aiming lines it´s possible to precisely plan my actions. And for the good camera work I´ve ditched "other" turn based games to come enjoy this one. In general if you know the rules the game sets for you, then it´s more certain in outcome than other tactical turn based games. And that´s what I like about this game; if I choose the right team with right equipment for the job then the outcome is mine to decide. Main factors to take into account are equipment+skills which decide my mercs aiming time and enemies are wallhacking aimbots.But both sides hit if the teamwork is planned correctly. If the rules are accepted from the very beginning then the game can be entertaining- can´t be anything better than setting team to nade the room and then rush in to clean the room with pump action shotguns and all that executing out in a few secs.Now to the AI part. Yep the AI and game mechanics is unfinished. It´s actually possible to go on stealth kills against lvl 1(maybe 2 also) enemies but but later in game against higher level AI the only way is rambo style. (DLC Point Blank was fun bc I could go with 45 cal silenced pistol and take out the whole garrison alone). In the early stage it´s important to choose correct merc for certain tasks, if it says expert in stealth, then stealth approach is doable etc...The most fun part is the start of the game, where I can play out different approaches till it goes rambo style with 2 squads of rambos.And for as old a game as this, it still looks good though unoptimised.Later in game there is indeed lot´s of micromanagement- all actions must be double checked on mercs, mules have to carry equipment over the map etc. But grinding money for equipment can be fun too.One good side of the game is that when I return to my favourite multiplayer FPS I always think more tactically and am doing much better. Haven´t experienced this with any other tactical turn based games, so it must do something right in the end...

This in itself wouldn't be such a big deal except that the spiders multiply it means that there are more items for the game to load when to go into the tactical view.  Eventually, there were so many spiders in the crate, I couldn't even retrieve the items I purchased because I had to scroll past all the spiders that had built up. 												In my mind, there are Four aspects that make up a game. There's the Story (within that, the character development), The Gameplay (within that, the difficulty), The Graphics (within this, the audio as well as the visual.) and the game's ability to be enjoyed (and replayability, of course.). Naturally, there's also bugs as an issue but, that's something that works out over time.JA:BIA is a Mediocre game. It has passable graphics and audio (for a relatively minor B grade game), next to no story (they didn't need to develop the story - the story existed from the origins of this game) and acceptable gameplay. The Gameplay is RTwP (real time with pause) which is a fantastic genre that people don't see enough of, or appreciate at all. While it's not the TBS of the original games, this particular form of gameplay is very entertaining, bringing one to the last note on this list, the game's ability to be enjoyed.If you have played the original JA games, you probably won't like this as a JA game. IF you pretend it's not a JA game, it's pretty fun. So, my word to you is to play it as if it were not a JA game, but simply a game to stand on its own two feet. It deserves some attention for its gameplay delivery. I'd give it a solid 6/10. It's not fantastic, but you'll definitely get your money's worth.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												There's a few things about this game that aren't quite the way I'd have done it... ridiculously low level caps, permanent armor degradation, and no custom mercenaries. If you can get past that, Jagged Alliance - Back in Action was quite possibly the best recent western-style squad based tactical RPG out at the time of release. The terrain is beautiful, and tactically significant. The weapons are varied and each can shine when paired with an appropriate combat style. The combat system is the smoothest and most satisfying attempt to meld real-time action and turn-based planning that I've ever played. Now that it's been patched, you can even adjust the tactical elements and difficulty to match the level of challenge you want. And if you're interested but not sold, Coreplay is among the disturbingly small club of developers that bothered to make a demo to introduce you to their product. Try it and see what you think... just don't charge toward the red marks as soon as the map loads. That's for bulls.

												While the game can be entertaining at times, there are major flaws with the design...- Mercenaries are traditionally retired Special Forces down to those with minimal Armed Forces training.. Regardless, anyone working in a team would know not to shoot their own team-mate; the biggest game-play flaw to-date is that your own men will shoot the other. I've tried in many different configurations from 2 to 3 men per team. When I try to have the front man crouch and the rear man stand ( as is one important form ) the rear-man ends up in front because of issues with pathing and the front man, now rear, shoots the rear man, now front... Same with 3 man team, I try to have 1 crouch and 2 stand ( so 2 standing fire on either side of the crouched shoulder ) but the issue still arises. No matter the positions whether all crouched, proned, standing or in various different settings ( so they can move together ) they end up shooting each other.- Pathing is terrible, team-mates get stuck in corners and run for ages before the system corrects the issue.- Tutorial is heavily scripted and if you complete an action prior to it asking ( such as repairing the weapon ) then the tutorial breaks and you can no longer continue.- Group pathing is also terrible, as mentioned in - number 1; the group does not move as one when you want it to if you want the game to be played as a RTS without setting up the space-bar system ( but players still don't move together even when you try ). Another issue is with rotation, ie you have finally got the crouched man in front and the standing man in rear, now when you want to move 90 to 180 degrees in another direction, it is reversed ( and lets hope the ai is in the correct position so your team-mates don't shoot each other ).- When you order an item from the "online store", there is no estimated time to arrival regardless of whether you select "Standard shipping" or "Expedited shipping".- Online Store Receipt doesn't list what you ordered.- Online Store E-Mail when your items arive doesn't state which order arrived with which items.- No common sense among mercenaries in this game. This game is more frustrating that enjoyable.- If you give a weapon to a recruit and leave to the world map while the recruit is pulling the weapon out ( read as: They received the weapon, the dialog closed, the animation is playing ) the money, the weapon and the recruit is lost. You have to find or buy a new weapon in order to recruit the person for a second time.- On level load, players randomly shoot their own team-player.- Kill cam resets YOUR camera settings ( and game-play continues without being able to stop it when active meaning it needs to be disabled in the gameplay options [ game-play is the right spot for it because it interferes with it ] )The game is riddled with bugs.

												Note, If you are a fan of JA, look at something else. If you are a fan of this, just go away, you will not like what I have to say about this sad, sorry, S.O.B. of a game. Most of my game time is because I left the game on overnight and did not notice until the next morning.I want to give this a good review, I really do. But in good concience, I can't. In fact I hate the blasted thing. And I have been putting off writing this in hopes that it would be fixed, but so much for that. This is the first Jagged Alliance game I have ever had  and at first I liked it, then I actually began playing it. The game is frought with bugs, logic failures and factual errors, alot of them. To begin with the game will crash ittermitantly for no particular reason and it is not my rig (MSI Redline modified by XoticPC). Then there are the other little annoying things, character pictures go all fuzzy and you sometimes pop around the map with lag, but I could live with that if it wern't for the gameplay. Oh god, here it comes. Your characters are absoutly clueless and need major micromanaging to keep them on target. You literally have to hold their hands through every single encouter. Who to aim at, kneel, stand, run, where to go ect. I would not be suprised if they needed instruction on how to wipe their virtal hinies. They will not even return fire unless given explicit orders to fire at a specific target. I can hear you yelling at me through your screen, "Use the Guard Mode!". Yes, you could use the guard mode but that does not use the full range of the weapon only acone of what the character can "see". With fog of war on this makes sense, with it off, not so much. Another problem, if you order them to move to a location and the dinkleberry pathefinder system doesn't think they can fit in just right, they bounce around in the space like so many pinballs cought between a pair of bumpers. In a combination of these two problems, you can actually kill off your whole squad with friendly fire. If you have lets say six guys lined up behind cover and somebody pops up on your flank while guard mode is on, the far character will actually drill rounds through the rest of the squad like a 10 year old playing CoD. Moving on to the other  bits, few of the vanilla guns have proper names, all grenades, cannon shots and tank rounds look like smoke grenades and the reloading is a bit too short for mgs. But the most game breaking thing about this is also the biggest logical error. If you leave the enemy alone long enough, you will be facing a bunch of Navy Seals guarding a garbage dump, no kidding, I saw 6 Spec Ops (Lvl 5 enemies) looking after Queen D's rubish pile. This is just stupid for lack of a better word, there are steep learning curves then there is this. This is worse than unfair, it is just totally illogical. It makes not sense to sit your best guys on your least important junk. I'm sorry but this just kills the game.For those like myself that like comprehensive stuff, I'll break it down.Concept 8/10I like the Idea behind the game, lead a gurrillia war against an opressive dictator with mercs and liberate the country, in other words, every JA game in the cookie oven. Still, it had so much potential and was dropped it in the mud. Tsk, tsk.Graphics 6/10They are not bad but are way under par for a title like this made a scant 3 years back. The whole thing just feel kind of janky. This inculudes the buggy gliches and whatnot.Interface 5/10Even worse than the graphics, still feels cheap and lacks fluidity to the placement to the buttons and some thigs are missing totally from the interface.Stability/Moddability 3/10Mods can be found for this If you look for them, but there are not that many, also, this does not have workshop available. When you do find a mod, only use one, mabe two if they are dissimilar because this is buggy as is and mods are notthe best thing to throw at something like that. Some mods do correct some of the problems with the game, but I have yet to find one that can fix that stupid enemy generator. I run a realism one to correct some of those aforementioned errors but that is like empting the ocean with a pale and shovel. And a good modder should not have to make up for the numerous♥♥♥♥♥♥ups by the devs.Gameplay -10/10Yes, I said negative 10, if you don't like that, tuff turkey. This just kills it for me, like I said above, there are aspects of the game that just make you want to hit something. Incredibly frusterating and totally illogical. The enemy just steamroles you if you do not skip about 70% of the areas and make a mad dash for the finish line. Yes,you can skip most of the game and just go for the jugular, but what is the bloody point of the game if you are just going to end it in 5 game days anyway? P.S. The DLCs are a rip off.Conclusion (11/5)/10 I ain't breaking out a calculator for this. Bad, it's just bad.So, the game could have been much better if the Devs game a darn. But as I played the game, I felt that the game had alot of rough edges, almost like it was done very quickly on a beer budget while trying to make a champagne title. Many of the aspects do not make sense and the map looks like an ink blot on constuction paper. In other words, this could be better played if you had Seal Team 6 an a couple of helicopters.  Now I know I am going to get a lot of "learn to play" BS out of the fans of this game, I have one thing to say to you, shut up. If somebody was shooting at you and you had a rifle in your hand would you just sit and stare into space? No you would pull the trigger and not wait for someone to tell you to do it. (Well, I would, if you have a 1000 plus hours on this game, lets face it, you live in your mom's basement and would soil yourself and have a heart attack if someone shot at you). Final take away, DO NOT BUY THIS!!!!!!!!!! If you want an RTS that has pause and has some RPG elements and feels like a gurrilla type thing, I got nothing for you, can't think of a thing for you sorry.Update: I have found a mod combo that does make this better and have found it to be more playable. However that does not change my views of the base game for which this review is for.

												A lot of people seem to hate this game becuase it is too different from its predecessors and to some extent I can see what the complaints are about, however I don't think the game is as bad as people claim. Before I wrote this review I went back to Jagged alliance and Jagged alliance 2, loved both those games and played them a lot (btw the ui in those two games haven't aged well, specially the first game).Jagged Alliance Back in action is more of a spiritual succesor rather than a "Jagged Alliance 3" and for that I think they did a decent job. The ui is much better than previous installments and the real time combat (which you can pause to give orders) is a refreshing additon that makes the game feel more fluent than previous installments. That being said I am a big fan of the Xcom remake by Firaxis and I can see the potential of turnbased combat done well. A future installment of Jagged Alliance could possibly add a optional feature where you could play "old school" with turnbased or real time. I don't find this to be a big issue.What I do think is a big issue with this game is lack of "finishing touches", kind of poor item configuration and lack of modifications such as in previous installments (i.e. combining different materials to make new items or improve current items). By finishing touches I am referring to items that seem to have the wrong stats (there are mods that reconfigure items to the proper stats and ammo type), there's a ton of useless items in game that have no use at all (During my first playthrough it took me quite some time to figure out the clock and broken controller couldn't be applied to C4 to make a bomb). The game lacks many features that would have been handy, such as improved tooltip, an option to carefully open doors (since every enemy on the map seem to hear you when you open a door for some reason), an actual sneak system (you know as in previous installments). The tool tip in the game doesn't really give much info, i.e. the different traits that the mercs have don't actually mention what bonuses they get for i.e. "Expert Melee" (Another thing that mods sorted). One of the features I really miss is the ability to train your mercs, which is really needed for most of the mercs you recruit from Arulco (or you'll end up with a lot of "mules"). You could obviously train them by having them fight, repair or act as medic, but most of them have so poor stats that they can't do any of that decently.Controls are good, I like the tactical system where you can give your mercs several commands and even sync their movements, however their pathfinding is horrible. More than once I've setup my mercs for an ambush while the last guy tries to run over people rather than around them and mess up my setup (since after a while the one being run up against moves to let the idiot pass). The fact that you never have to sleep is handy but unrealistic and makes the game faster paced than it should be. Rather than sleeping you can simply give your mercs something to eat to regain stamina. My "elite" squad didn't sleep for 7 days straight while they went from sector to sector and cleared it all out (and since there are plenty of medical supplies and food this was never an issue). The resting system from previous installments forced you to be more tactical about your choices, so you wouldn't be vulnerable during your main squads downtime. The music in the game is ok, works well with the combat and at least I didn't get bothered by it in the long run. I think the reason I like this game so much is more about the potential it has/had rather than the actual outcome. It had so much potential, but it seems almost as if the developers didn't have time to finish the game, it certainly lacks polish.If you enjoyed this game I recommend trying out Jagged Alliance Crossfire, pretty much the same game but with a new mission. There are also some dlcs with just a tactical map mission (I tried one of them which was with Igor, Shadow and Fox), was quite fun but lasts you for about 30-60min depending on your playstyle).If you do play this game my suggestion is play on hard since normal is simply too easy (keep in mind this is a tactical game your mercs are not rambo) and when you have finished the game try one of the good mods i.e. Realistic mod by Killatomate (http://www.moddb.com/mods/realistic-rebalancing-mod), which sorts out many of the issues I've mentioned.
